It‚Äôs unclear how many we have in hospitals today, but the Strategic National Stockpile told CNN that it held approximately 16,660 ventilators before the coronavirus response, though other estimates have varied. (11/19)

The United States has seen more than 65,000 confirmed cases of #COVID„Éº19 so far. If we use the data from China, that would mean at least 1,400 people need ventilators right now in the US. But we‚Äôre only in the beginning of our crisis. (8/19)

As coronavirus cases rise across the country, a major concern is we won‚Äôt have enough of these machines. That means doctors in the US may soon have to decide who gets a ventilator and who doesn‚Äôt. (4/19)

The ventilator is one of the most important pieces of equipment in the fight against coronavirus. If a patient can‚Äôt breathe on their own, a ventilator helps move air in and out of the lungs for them - providing oxygen and also, importantly, removing carbon dioxide. It is worth noting that while this trial failed ‚Äî it ‚Äòfailed quickly,‚Äô which is also very important. That way we don‚Äôt lose precious resources or time. Several other trials are currently underway. #coronavirus

Researchers were enthusiastic about this trial because this drug combination was widely available and could be prescribed immediately. The first patient had been in enrolled in the trial just one week after the novel #coronavirus was first identified.
A clinical trial for #coronavirus, using two HIV drugs on patients with severe illness, found no benefit beyond standard care.

And, in places where face masks aren‚Äôt available, health care providers now asked to consider using a bandana or a scarf while caring for patients with #coronavirus. (Those are obviously not going to work. They don‚Äôt even provide a ‚Äòfalse‚Äô sense of comfort)

Consider this: In communities with substantial community transmission of #coronavirus ‚Äî exposed health care providers, even if they have symptoms, will be allowed to keep caring for patients if they wear a face mask. (Previously, they would‚Äôve been quarantined)

And, there is no such thing as a perfect level of preparation ‚Äî being neither over prepared or under prepared. So, if we have to err on one side or the other, let‚Äôs be over prepared on this one. #COVID19 https://t.co/wP3zcRNb8H

Uncertainty cannot and should not lead to inaction. 

Of course everyone wants more certainty around #coronavirus , but in the mean time we must still act. The hospitals need to be prepared and we need to physically distance from each other, at least for a while.

President Trump predicts the coronavirus outbreak could start to subside in July or August of this year, although he said the virus could continue to be a threat even longer. #CoronavirusOutbreak

This is the case fatality ratio in China based on pre-existing conditions. Heart disease was the biggest risk factor, followed by diabetes, lung disease and hypertension.  #coronavirus 19/22 https://t.co/ztTzyHcHJh

China recently approved the use of favilavir, an antiviral drug used for flu, as an investigational therapy. There are more than 100 clinical trials to test new and repurposed drugs against the novel #coronavirus. 17/22

Patients with COVID-19 receive care similar to other viral pneumonias. Typically supportive care and oxygen. Steroids are not generally recommended. Anecdotal evidence that remdesivir, an antiviral drug may help. Clinical trials are underway. #COVID19 16/22
The reproductive number (Ro) is estimated to be between 2 and 3. That means a single infected person can spread the infection to 2 to 3 people. For reference: flu (Ro) is 1.28 #CoronavirusUSA 14/22

The virus appears to be transmitted through large respiratory droplets and fomites (infected surfaces).  Although viral material has been found in stool there is no live virus there so unlikely that there is fecal transmission. #CoronaVirusUpdates  13/22

There is quite possibly an intermediate host between bats and humans. Early evidence has pointed to the pangolin, one of the most illegally traded animal in the world #CoronavirusPandemic 10/22 https://t.co/SiQwF2FL57

It is surprising this hasn't yet spread more widely in India, Africa or Latin America. That is worth noting and following. Some have said it is ‚Äúwarm weather‚Äù but would not count on that. #CoronavirusOutbreak 9/22

Worth remembering China is a fairly homogenous population. As the virus spreads to countries with more diverse populations, such as the United States, we may see different patterns of disease, such as more severe illness in younger people. #CoronaVirus 8/22
It could also be that there is a higher prevalence of smoking among men in China, as compared to women #CoronavirusOutbreak 7/22

Early data shows that Asian males have a large number of ACE2-expressing cells in the lung, which may explain the male predominance of coronavirus infection and disease. Men are more likely to become infected and ill from the coronavirus. 6/22
Inadequate surfactant leads to acute respiratory distress syndrome, known as ARDS. #COVID19 5/22
